text:
Broadway, west side, at Thomas Street (unopened), showing the old New York Hospital buildings that stood here from the American Revolution to 1869, when their function was removed to the new hospital on West 15th Street. The structure shown is the second, as the first (cornerstone laid in 1775) was destroyed by fire prior to completion. It was immediately rebuilt and nearly complete when the Revolution began. The unfinished building was occupied by the British and Hessian soldiers as a barrack and hospital, and it was not until January, 1791, that it was in a proper condition to receive patients.

Prior to 1869

Gift of Urbrock Collection

title: Broadway, West Side. Thomas to Franklin St.
Broadway, East Side. Pearl to Franklin St.

text:
318 to 304 Broadway, east side, south from Pearl to and including Duane Streets, showing a row of buildings (Nos. 318 to 306) occupying this block front. No. 304 is the 16-story Vincent Building at the S.E. corner of Duane Street. These structures remain the same today (1937).

June 3, 1904.

Brown Brothers.

Lafayette Street, west side, from Pearl (left) to Worth (right) Streets, showing the plant of the "Il Progresso Italo-Americano," an Italian daily newspaper, at the N.W. corner of Pearl Street. The tall structure (16 stories) shown across the roof tops, is the Central Syndicate Building, 320-324 Broadway, at the N.E. corner of Pearl Street. The ornate clock and atlas affair on the right, is atop the New York Life Insurance Co. Building.

September 26, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

320 to 348 Broadway, east side, north from Pearl to Leonard Streets, showing prominently the 16-story Central Syndicate Building (No. 320-324), at the N.E. corner of Pearl Street. The 12-story structure with the ornate tower appearing on the left is the N.Y. Life Insurance Co. Building. Shown in the foreground are the upper stories of two 5-story buildings, Nos. 318 and 316, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Pearl Street. About 1928.

Edwin Levick.

A Chatham Square view as seen from the east side of square at Pearl Street and East Broadway. A Third Avenue Surface car is shown in the foreground, stopping here enroute to the United States Post Office via the Bowery.

March 6, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, from a different angle.

September 30, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

About 1936.

(1) Broadway, east side, north from, but not including Pearl Street, showing the New York Life Insurance Co. Building (building with clock tower), from Catherine Lane to Leonard Street.

April 18, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A similar view showing in addition the lower portions of the 16 story Central Syndicate Building at the right. This structure bears No. 320-24 Broadway and is at the N.E. corner of Pearl Street.

June 12, 1938.
